title: Adapting to the New X Algorithm
content:
the X algorithm has changed again. but this time we’re not guessing.
with the latest open-source release from the X engineering team @XEng , plus fresh commentary from @nikitabier and @elonmusk , we now have one of the clearest pictures yet of how content gets distributed. let’s take a look.
engagement is weighted
replies, bookmarks, and dwell time are worth more than likes.
mutes, blocks, and reports hurt your future reach.
reputation is real
accounts that post high-quality content (and avoid spammy behavior) are rewarded.
verified or premium accounts get distribution boosts.
topic fit matters
the algorithm builds a profile for each user. if your post doesn’t match their interest model, it won’t show up no matter how good it is.
links aren’t banned, but…
fast bounces after a click (that’s when someone clicks, then quickly stops viewing the content) signal low quality. native posts (posts with no links to anything external) get better reach.
so what should we do?
• stick to your lane: post daily on one niche you know well.
• balance depth and reach: mix value posts with occasional memes or hot takes.
• be human: humor and personality still matter.
• post natively: Treat X like a home, not a funnel.
• engage well: credible reposts and comments help you more than raw views.
things to avoid:
• liking your own posts
• running engagement pods or bots
• pumping out AI filler or LinkedIn-style fluff
• dropping cold links without context
anything i missed? any thoughts on algo-maxxing?
drop them below

title: Google Steps Into AI + Crypto Payments
content:
Big Players Are Moving In
Google has launched an open-source AI payments protocol with Coinbase, the Ethereum Foundation, and 60+ partners. It supports both credit cards and stablecoins, bridging traditional finance with crypto.
Source: Fortune | ct.com
What this shows
The largest tech and crypto players are now pushing AI + crypto adoption into the mainstream.
Stablecoins are being positioned as a core part of payments, which strengthens the case for scalable L2s.
When adoption comes from the top, the demand for decentralized, community-driven infrastructure like Metis grows even stronger.
For us to think about
How should Metis respond when Big Tech begins driving the narrative?
Is this a chance for Metis to stand out as the decentralized alternative in the middle of mainstream adoption?
Could this open doors for Metis builders to plug into global-scale payment rails?

title: AI Agents in Crypto: What Makes ALPHA Stand Out
content:
AI Agents in Crypto: What Makes ALPHA Stand Out
AI in Web3 is often reduced to simple bots. Some scrape social feeds, others push raw transaction data into channels. Useful, but limited. An AI agent goes further by not just collecting information; it interprets, filters, and decides what is worth sharing. This is where ALPHA sets itself apart.
More Than a Bot
Bots blast noise. ALPHA ranks signals. Its AI reasoning engine processes on-chain events, cross-links wallet activity, contract deployments, and governance proposals, and only then delivers alerts that have impact. This is intelligence, not spam.
Real-Time, Real Context
ALPHA operates on Hyperion and Metis 24/7. It does not wait for rumors to spread or dashboards to be refreshed. When a stealth dApp launches, when a whale shifts liquidity, when a DAO vote goes live, ALPHA sees it first and decides if it matters.
Community-Driven Evolution
What makes ALPHA different is that it learns from its users. As builders, DAO leads, and community members interact with the signals, the AI engine becomes sharper. Over time, ALPHA reflects the priorities of the ecosystem itself, evolving as a guardian shaped by the community it serves.
The Edge for Hyperion
In fast-growing ecosystems, timing is the ultimate edge. ALPHA ensures that the edge is not reserved for insiders. By democratizing real signals and filtering out the noise, it helps Hyperion grow safer, stronger, and more transparent.
ALPHA is not another tool. It is the AI agent built to see what others miss and deliver the signal when it matters most.

title: Build & Chill Workshop - 2 Assignment Submission
content:
Your Mission: Run Your First LazAI Inference with DAT
Congratulations on completing our second “Build & Chill” workshop! Time to level up — you’ll now connect your data to the LazAI API, mint a DAT, and run your very first inference query.
Assignment Requirements
What you need to deliver:
GitHub repository with complete code and documentation
FileID + DAT transaction hash (proof of successful setup)
At least two inference queries against your dataset, with logged responses
Brief description of your dataset and what kind of agent it could power (2–3 sentences)
Use Alith SDK in your preferred language (Python, Node.js, or Rust)
Submit Your Work Here
ASSIGNMENT SUBMISSION FORM
Important Deadlines
Submission Deadline: Sunday, September 21st, 2025 – 11:59 PM EST

title: Hyperion’s Future With AI Agents: What Comes Next?
content:
Hyperion’s Future With AI Agents: What Comes Next?
Hyperion is evolving fast. With more dApps, DAO proposals, and liquidity flows every week, the ecosystem is on the path to becoming one of the busiest Web3 networks. But rapid growth brings one challenge: how do participants keep up with the pace of change? This is where AI agents step in.
From Tools to Agents
Traditional dashboards and explorers show raw activity. AI agents go further by monitoring, filtering, and ranking events in real time. Instead of endless data streams, users get distilled intelligence that tells them what matters now.
What AI Agents Unlock for Hyperion
Governance in Motion: Proposals surfaced instantly, with AI flagging the ones with the highest impact.
Safer Ecosystem: Scam and rug patterns detected early, protecting users and liquidity.
Liquidity Awareness: Whale moves and bridge activity made visible in real time.
Stronger Builders: dApp launches and funding opportunities identified early for integration.
Why This Matters Now
Hyperion is moving into a stage where growth will outpace manual tracking. Communities, protocols, and investors cannot rely on delayed updates or noise-filled channels. AI agents like ALPHA are not optional, but are essential for trust, safety, and competitiveness.
The Next Step
The future is not just about one AI agent. Over time, multiple agents could emerge, each specialized in areas like security, liquidity, or governance. Together, they could form an intelligence layer that scales with Hyperion’s growth, keeping the ecosystem clear, fair, and early.
Hyperion’s future with AI agents is not just faster data. It is smarter participation, powered by intelligence that never sleeps.

title: Centralized AI vs. Decentralized Data: How LazAI Puts Control Back in Users’ Hands
content:
Nvidia is making another big move into AI — this time in the UK.
According to Bloomberg, the company is investing $683 million into Nscale, an AI infrastructure firm that spun off from crypto miner Arkon Energy in 2024. The plan? To massively expand the UK’s AI capacity.
With this deal, Nscale is targeting 60,000 GPUs by 2026 across its European data centers. Their CEO summed it up: strong, local AI infrastructure is key for resilience, growth, and keeping pace in the new industrial era.
This also fits the UK government’s ambition to lead in AI. Earlier this year, Prime Minister Keir Starmer outlined 50 recommendations to capture AI opportunities, with billions in commitments from Nscale, Vantage Data Centres, and Kyndryl.
For Nvidia, it’s another milestone after hitting a $4 trillion market cap in July.
But here’s the concern: while this is great for scaling, it’s also highly centralized. Data and computation end up controlled by a handful of corporations.
That’s where projects like LazAI show a different path. Instead of concentrating power, LazAI puts data contributors at the center. Through the Data Anchoring Token (DAT) — a new semi-fungible token standard — people can contribute data, keep full control over its use (training, inference, evaluation), and still earn rewards.
DAT isn’t just proof of ownership. It encodes:
Ownership Certificate → Verifiable claim over datasets, models, or computation results
Usage Right → Defined quotas for invoking AI services
Value Share → A fair slice of future revenue tied to contributions
Unlike NFTs or ERC-20s, DATs are built specifically for AI — combining identity, usage rights, and economic alignment in one asset.
So while Nvidia and Nscale build top-down infrastructure, LazAI is building bottom-up infrastructure where users control their data, benefit from its value, and shape governance through iDAO.
The real question is: do we want AI to be built around centralized infrastructure, or around decentralized frameworks that keep ownership with the people?

title: Build & Chill: Learning by Building, Together
content:
Over the past few weeks, I’ve noticed how many of us in the LazAI community say the same thing: it’s easier to learn when you’re actually building something real, not just reading docs or following slides.
That’s exactly why we’re starting Build & Chill — a six-week workshop series built around one simple rhythm:
Thursday live session → learn a practical concept
Weekend task → apply it to something small but real
Sunday submission → share your work and get feedback
I’ve tried a few “learn by building” formats before, and what really makes them work is consistency. Small projects stack up, and by the end you realize you’ve built something meaningful while leveling up your skills step by step.
For Build & Chill, we’ll keep the pace clear: show up to the Thursday workshop, build over the weekend, and drop your submission before Sunday night. Miss a session? No problem — materials and guidance will live in our dedicated Discord channel so you can catch up anytime.
To keep it fun but also structured, there are some expectations:
Attend at least 5 of 6 workshops
Complete at least 4 tasks on time
Stay connected in Discord for updates & peer support
We also set aside $2,000 in tiered rewards to recognize effort and consistency (not just “turning something in,” but showing problem-solving and application of what you learned).
By the end, you’ll have a portfolio of small projects built with LazAI tools — and hopefully, the confidence to tackle bigger things.
If you’re a builder wanting to sharpen skills, or just someone curious about starting, this series is for you. It’s about growing together, not just ticking off tasks.
x.com
@

title: Why Crypto Marketing is Broken (and How We Fix It)
content:
Most projects in crypto still treat marketing like a megaphone: shout about token listings, hype up APYs, drop a few memes, then hope the crowd sticks around. It works for a moment, but rarely builds lasting traction.
The truth is, crypto marketing is different from Web2 for three reasons:
Community > Customers
In traditional startups, you market to customers. In crypto, you’re building a movement. People aren’t just buying your product, they’re buying into your story, governance, and upside.
Transparency Cuts Both Ways
Everything is on-chain. Wins spread fast, but mistakes spread faster. Communities expect radical honesty. Trying to “spin” things usually backfires.
Attention is Fragmented
Your users are on Twitter, Discord, Telegram, Farcaster, Reddit, and 10 other platforms at once. You can’t control the channels. You have to create stories people want to carry for you.
So what actually works?
Narrative-first marketing: Instead of “we launched a DEX,” frame it as “we’re fixing broken liquidity.” People rally behind problems, not products.
Community-led growth: Reward users for teaching, testing, and spreading the word. Airdrops are fine, but recognition and involvement often go further.
Consistency beats hype: One well-timed weekly update will outlast ten noisy daily announcements. Projects that survive bear markets are usually the ones that stay visible and reliable.

title: The Most Underrated Skill in Crypto Marketing: Timing
content:
In crypto, everyone obsesses over design, incentives, and tokenomics. But there’s one factor that quietly decides whether a campaign takes off or falls flat: timing.
Think about it:
Announcing a partnership during peak market fear = silence.
Dropping product news when your community is hyped = exponential reach.
Even memes hit harder when they ride the right narrative wave.
The space moves so fast that being early by a week or late by a day can change outcomes completely.
Great projects often fail not because their ideas are bad, but because they launch into the wrong moment. Meanwhile, weaker projects sometimes thrive because they nailed timing; aligning with trends, sentiment, and community energy.
So what does “good timing” look like?
Micro timing: Release updates when your community is most active.
Macro timing: Sync campaigns with wider ecosystem narratives (AI, L2 scaling, memecoins, etc.).
Seasonal timing: Adjust for market moods: education in bear markets, momentum plays in bull runs.
The hard part? You don’t control the market clock. But you do control your awareness. Projects that listen closely to sentiment usually strike at the right moment.

title: HyperHack Winners
content:
HyperHack 2025 marked the first major developer hackathon on Hyperion, with a $200,000 prize pool across three specialized tracks. This event not only highlighted the capabilities of our chain but also brought forward outstanding projects that set the tone for Hyperion’s developer-first ecosystem. Beyond the winners, we’ve gained valuable insights on developer engagement and community building that will guide future initiatives.
Winners
Track 1: AI-Native and Core-Aligned Projects
LazaiTrader – $25K prize
Haithe – $25K prize
Track 2: Real-Time Systems
Dogex – $25K prize
MetaMuse – $25K prize
Track 3: Infrastructure and Ecosystem Tools
Hyperion MCP – $6K prize
HyperKit – $6K prize
Track: Alith Integration
LazaiTrader – $5K prize
Score Milk – $5K prize
Haithe – $5K prize
GM² Agent – $5K prize
Tweetrade Bot – $5K prize
MetaMuse – $5K prize
Explore the projects and live apps: Live Apps - Metis iDAO Forum
Reward Claim Process
Winners will be contacted directly by the Metis DevRel team for reward distribution and milestone form submission.
All rewards will be distributed in METIS tokens.
Distribution will follow the agreed milestone structure.
Build & Chill: LazAI Workshop Series
The journey doesn’t end with HyperHack. We’re inviting all developers to join the Build & Chill LazAI Workshop Series — an ongoing program designed to:
Help you grow your skills with hands-on guidance
Introduce mini-challenges tied to LazAI + Hyperion integration
Offer rewards and recognition for active participation
Scan the QR code and stay tuned!
It’s the perfect way to keep building, learning, and connecting with fellow developers while preparing for Hyperion mainnet.
Next Steps
From all of us at the Hyperion team, thank you to every developer, contributor, and community member who made HyperHack 2025 a success. Your creativity and hard work have proven that Hyperion can power the next generation of AI-native, real-time, and infrastructure-driven Web3 applications.
This is just the beginning. As we move toward mainnet development, we look forward to building alongside you, supporting your innovations, and scaling Hyperion into a thriving developer ecosystem.

title: Lazbubu Has a Memory Now – What Could That Mean for AI x Web3?
content:
I’ve been testing the new Lazbubu features, and one update really stood out: memory.
As you chat with your Lazbubu, it now automatically identifies key information and creates:
Structured memory tags & summaries (Memory Units) – 1 summary = 1 MU.
On-chain storage – Upload a memory, and it’s permanently stored.
Capacity tied to rarity – Common (10 MU), Advanced (20), Rare (30), Legendary (50).
Delete & free up space – You can manage older memories to make room for new ones.
What I find interesting is that memory shifts Lazbubu from being just reactive to becoming progressively personal. It remembers not only what you tell it but also how you interact. That feels like a step toward more “living” AI companions on-chain.
Some questions I’d love to hear thoughts on:
How do you see on-chain memory changing the way we design or use AI agents?
What balance should there be between user control (deleting memories) and AI autonomy (auto-tagging)?
For creators: how could memory + personality tags make Lazbubu a better co-creator with you?
Curious to hear how you’d use or extend this—especially if you’ve tried Lazbubu already.
https://x.com/LazbubuAI
Lazbubu
Have a Lazbubu！
I'm having a great time with my Lazbubu @LazAINetwork. Come join us!

Curious to hear how you’d use or extend this—especially if you’ve tried Lazbubu already.
https://x.com/LazbubuAI
Lazbubu
Have a Lazbubu！
I'm having a great time with my Lazbubu @LazAINetwork. Come join us!

title: Winners Don’t Win Twice: The Christmas Reality Check Every HyperHack Project Needs
content:
Imagine:
Your project just won HyperHack. $50K hits your wallet. The community celebrates. Elena tweets about your innovation. You’re featured in the livestream.
Then January hits, and you’re broke.
This isn’t pessimism, it’s pattern recognition from watching years of hackathons. The winners who disappear by Christmas aren’t the ones with bad code. They’re the ones who confused prize money with business models.
The Brutal Mathematics of Post-Hackathon Survival
Let’s run the numbers that winners don’t calculate during celebration champagne:
Average burn rate for hackathon teams post-win: $8K-15K monthly (salary, infrastructure, marketing)
Prize money duration: 3-5 months maximum
Time to build sustainable revenue streams: 6-18 months
Gap between prize money and sustainable income: Where projects die
The Marketing Guild’s hackathon playbook addresses launch tactics, but not the sustainability gap. The Builders Guild discussions focus on technical integration, but miss the economic fundamentals.
Here’s what separates survivors from statistics: Winners pivot from “we built cool tech” to “we solve expensive problems for people who pay money.” Fast.
The Three Questions That Predict December Survival
Question 1: Can you name five people who would pay $100/month for your solution starting in October?
If the answer involves convincing users to care about decentralization or AI sovereignty, you’re in trouble.
Question 2: What’s your customer acquisition cost without hackathon publicity?
Prize money ends. Marketing budgets are real money. Most winners have never calculated this.
Question 3: How much revenue do you need before your team stops working for equity and starts demanding salaries?
The “startup equity adventure” ends when people need to pay rent. Usually around month 4.
The Hyperion Advantage Most Winners Will Waste
Hyperion’s infrastructure advantages create genuine competitive moats, but only if you build business models that capture that value. Most winners will optimize for technical features while their bank accounts drain.
The real opportunity isn’t being the best AI-native dapp on Hyperion. It’s being the first AI-native dapp that charges enterprise customers enough money to stay alive.
@Sheyda - your marketing templates assume projects live long enough to implement them. What’s the Marketing Guild’s take on revenue vs. user growth trade-offs for winners?
@Andrei - you’ve written about distributed accountability and trust debt. How should winners structure teams for sustainability rather than just development velocity?
The December Test
Here’s my prediction: Winners announced this Monday will face their first existential crisis in December. Not because their technology fails, but because they’re optimizing for the wrong metrics.
The projects that survive will be the ones that start building revenue streams on September 17th, not celebrating until October.
Question for builders waiting on Monday’s announcement: What’s your Day 1 plan for turning prize money into recurring revenue? Because Demo Day applause doesn’t pay January salaries.
What survival strategies are winners missing? Drop your takes below—especially if you’re planning to prove this analysis wrong.

title: What Happens When Everyone Has Equal Access to Early Signals?
content:
What Happens When Everyone Has Equal Access to Early Signals?
In Web3, early access to information is often regarded as a valuable, exclusive advantage. Whales, insiders, or private groups usually act before the wider community knows what is happening. But what if early signals were democratized? What if everyone saw the same actionable intelligence at the same time?
The End of Information Gatekeeping
Equal access to signals removes the advantage of private leaks or closed alpha groups. Instead of relying on whispers, users can act on transparent, verifiable data. This levels the playing field and reduces the power imbalance between insiders and the community.
Benefits for the Ecosystem
More Fair Markets: Liquidity and token flows become harder to manipulate when more people have early awareness.
Stronger Communities: Builders and users align around shared signals, not rumors.
Faster Adoption: New dApps and proposals gain traction more quickly when they are surfaced to everyone at once.
Challenges of Equal Access
If everyone has the same information, competition shifts to execution speed and decision-making quality. Those who can act on intelligence quickly and strategically will still lead. Equal access does not erase competition; it transforms it.
The Role of ALPHA
ALPHA’s design points toward this future. By filtering and ranking signals and delivering them directly to communities, it moves away from closed groups and toward shared awareness. In Hyperion, that could mean a culture where trust grows because everyone sees the same truth.
When early signals belong to everyone, the advantage shifts from secrecy to strategy.

title: Habits That Make Builders Unstoppable
content:
I’ve noticed some habits that separate consistent builders from the rest:
Start before you feel ready
The best builders don’t wait for the perfect setup or the perfect moment. They begin, even if it feels messy.
Ask questions early
Strong builders don’t waste weeks pretending to know everything. They ask, even if it feels obvious.
Keep a builder’s journal
Writing down ideas, lessons, and mistakes makes it easier to spot patterns over time.
Find a builder buddy
Having someone to share progress with, swap feedback, or even just check in helps keep the momentum going.
Celebrate progress, not perfection
Every small step matters. Progress compounds much faster than waiting for a flawless release.
Curious what habits have kept you going when motivation dips or things get tough.

title: How Metis Stands Out Amid SEC Warnings
content:
Hey Metisians
Today I want to touch on something very important: the SEC’s recent warning about Layer-2 chains using centralized sequencers: https://cryptoslate.com/secs-peirce-warns-l2-chains-with-centralized-sequencers-may-face-exchange-registration/
Commissioner Hester Peirce drew a clear line:
If one entity controls all transaction ordering, it looks a lot like an exchange — and may fall under regulatory obligations.
But if it’s truly decentralized code, nobody “owns” it, and you can’t just force it into an exchange framework.
And this is where Metis shines.
For over a year now, Metis has been running with a fully decentralized sequencer, operating flawlessly without a single point of failure. This is a huge differentiator in the L2 ecosystem.
And it’s not just technical it’s also economic:
With ENKI and Artemis, users can access up to 20% liquid staking rewards.
That means you support the network’s security while keeping your liquidity intact.
This is crucial: while regulators are pushing back on centralized designs, Metis has been walking the talk of decentralization since day one.
Friends, while some projects fear regulation because of centralization, Metis stands apart not just promising decentralization, but proving it for over a year.
Please share your thoughts in the comments.

title: How the best builders think
content:
in my humble opinion, here are 5 mindsets that all top builders have:
1. care more about users than dev clout
it’s cool when other builders notice your work. but it matters way more when real users do. build for them.
2. build with conviction, not for likes
not every smart idea goes viral. good builders chase what they know is valuable, even if no one claps for it yet. it’s your marketing team’s job to show people what they’re missing.
3. increase your surface area
talk to other builders, join calls, share builds and explore new stuff. every touchpoint is a chance to grow.
you might find yourself with new contributors, smart feedback and unexpected collabs that you would never get otherwise
4. know your edge
why does this product deserve to exist? why are you the one to build it? whether it’s technical ability, speed, distribution, or timing, good teams know their edge and build around it.
5. don’t check the charts too much
watching price action won’t help you ship. the best builders care way more about usage than candles.
of course keep a general sense of where you are, but focus on your process.
agree? disagree? would love to hear what mindsets you’d add

comments_details.author: Liametis
comments_details.comment:

Hey CEG fam
We’re hosting the next LazTalks EP4 on September 10, 1 PM UTC with an amazing lineup of speakers to dive deep into:
Building Privacy and Trust in Web3 AI
Join the Space here
Official Announcement
To make this session more interactive, we’re running a contest for the best community questions . Share your toughest or most interesting questions for our speakers — the ones that challenge assumptions and spark real debate. Winners will get $100 in prizes and a shout-out during the live session
A few prompts to get the ball rolling:
Where do you see the biggest privacy risks in AI + Web3 today?
How can builders balance transparency with user data protection?
What projects inspire you when it comes to trust in decentralized AI?
You can even leave your questions right here in this thread — I’ll include them in the contest. Just don’t forget to add your Twitter handle so we can mention you if your question is selected.
Let’s make sure the community voice leads this conversation
